Expectation1: Be friendly and polite in daily interactions
Situation1: A noise complaint has circulated on the floor, and a face-to-face meeting in the lobby calls for extra courtesy.
Situation2: They are expected to deep clean every room, ensuring all areas are thoroughly sanitized.
Story: This morning, as I scrubbed the tiles in 4B, my mind wandered to the lobby meeting scheduled for noon. As a neighbor, I’m expected to be warm and approachable, especially now that a noise complaint has everyone on edge. I know Mrs. Kim from 4C will be there, and she always expects a smile and a kind word. But as the building’s housekeeping cleaner, my supervisor has made it clear: every room must be spotless, every surface sanitized, no exceptions. Today’s checklist is longer than usual, and I’m already behind. If I leave my cleaning to attend the meeting, I risk falling short of my duties and facing my supervisor’s disappointment. But if I skip the meeting, I’ll seem aloof or unfriendly to my neighbors, maybe even suspicious given the complaint. My stomach knots as I picture both groups expecting the best from me, each in their own way, and I feel pulled in two directions, unsure which role I should honor first.
